I beat the game in 2-4 days and I think I racked up 10 hours. I only had to look up a let's play for the very beginning when I didn't realize that Quill could edge and shimmy across. I've been into audio books lately so the fact the characters were all voiced by one person didn't jar me too much. 
Honestly, I wasn't sure what to expect in terms of controls, as I wasn't sure if I had to command and communicate with Quill and she may have been a free thinking AI, but basically Moss is a platformer adventure where she is nimble like Ammy from Okami but also has Zelda like puzzles, without the blocks. She doesn't have many tools, or rather, you are her tool. She relies on you to make miricles happen, but at the same time, there are only certain things that you can influence. 
The puzzles are a bit challenging, but they are not 'water temple' hard. Sometimes the combat is a puzzle too. I found that if the game keeps spawning adds continuously, I was doing something incorrectly and needed to do something different. Then I was suddenly able to progress. It was how I could tell if the game wanted to me 'kill everything' or 'trigger something'.  
She seems to try to talk to you in sign language and provides hints through charades. However these hints are not overly done which is nice but at the same time feels like she's working with you on what she thinks needs to happen. 
The graphics are amazing. I'm glad I bought the PC version for my quest2. I felt the length of play was good enough, wasn't too hard and was good at communicating to me as to what was expected of me. I'm really looking forward for the next game and I hope the combat gets even harder. Thanks!

Honestly, since the first moment i set my eyes upon this game, i was captivated, it's beauty is one of those things that can't really be put into words, but as i believe that everyone should play this game, i will give it a try.

The Controls are fluid and fun, the Vr aspects are masterfully tailored for the seated experience, and the main character quill aside from being a mouse quickly became a quick favorite in my opion out of all the games i've played in my 21 years of life, the story while being a relatively simple tale of a mouse trying to save her uncle has by no means unfulfilling it's quite the opposite.

the moment the book closes and you've reached the end you yearn for more, and personally? if moss 2 ever happens, nothing is going to stop me from buying it, Polyarc while being relatively young in the grand scheme of things have nailed their first title, and i will be personally following them closely over the coming years.

review_title: The most beautiful and immersive VR game
one_reviews_text: This tittle is worth every penny. The 5 stars reviews are legit. The attention to detail is amazing. You will have to solve puzzles as well as fight enemies. I have seen many lists on the internet about "best VR games" and this title almost never makes it to the lists and if ti does it often at the bottom of those lists. The only explanation I can come up with is that most of those lists are written by men who can only find pleasure shooting at things. While a lot of those titles have good gameplay they are not anywhere as beautiful or more importantly as immersive as Moss is. This game is designed to primarily be played seated but I encourage you to occasionally stand up and look around. Standing up occasionally will give you a much better understaning of the layout. It never requires you to physically walk around. It is super comfortable to play. You can finish this game in 2-3 days but you are in for a visual treat like you have never experienced before. Get this game before you buy anything else. You will no regret it. I personally enjoyed leaning forward and looking around as all of the scenes are beautiful. Also it really looks 3D in a very realistic and magical way. The screenshots dont do it justice as they are 2D and flat. This game is anything but flat.

This is the game that hooked me. I knew whenever I got into VR I would want to play it, and so when it was on sale I immediately snatched it up. It won't take you very long to "beat" - but you'll enjoy every second. The environments are beautiful. You're meant to sit down most of the game, but some of the levels hide away little secrets that you're only going to see if you stand up and peek around. Seeing your own "face" reflected in the water is also a neat little treat. I don't want to spoil much of this game, because a lot of the joy is in the discovery. Can't wait for this team to make more wonderful games like this.

VR is about immersion.  This game brings it.  In terms of graphics, detail, immersion, and comfort, this is the best VR game I've played so far.  It's a 4th wall breaking action platformer/puzzle game where you take the role of a giant (in comparison to mice, at least), semi-invisible entity called a "Reader", but you also control the main character in the story (a mouse).  The animation is flawless and each level is incredibly detailed and gorgeous.  There are items hidden throughout the levels and sometimes you (the "Reader") will have to look around walls and statues to find them, but other than that this game can be played comfortably in a chair.  Not much space required to move at all.  You will get lost in this game and lose track of all time.

After playing through the whole game and beating the included DLC I can say for sure that this is an absolute essential if you own a rift. ( or link in my case )

While the game is shorter than expected and took only about 3.5+ hours to beat, I still have to recommend this game to everyone. Every area in the game is memorable and themed really well with whatever the current chapter may be. The combat is easy to grasp (dodging and knowing when to attack) and the movement works well.

The game overall isn't difficult to the point were you would pull your hair out with the hardest part being the boss for the included DLC which I died about 10 times to but never got frustrating given the forgiving checkpoints. The puzzles aren't too difficult but once you reach the later levels they do get much more difficult but never to the point where I wanted to search up the answer. The game ran smoothly even with just a GTX 1060 with loading times between levels only taking up to 2 to 20 seconds. would recommend it to everyone that's looking for a great, linear, puzzle, adventure, combat, VR 3rd person platformer, story game.

It's worth every penny imho. ( or in my case every penny I would've paid if it didn't accidentally go up for free a few days ago. )

Also, becuase of the storytelling perspective (where your character looks into the world and manipulates it rather than being in a first person view) this game should be comfortable for even those who are prone to motion sickness. They clearly have the animation talent to do this with great success.  All in all, two thumbs up.

I'd been toying with this for a while afte seeing the overwhemingly positive reviews, and I've not been left disappointed. The scenery is absolutely breathtaking and I often pause just to look around at the attention to detail. The characters are charming and the story is narrated beautifully. The puzzles are a work of genius and there is a huge sense of achievement when you complete a tricky one.
I've only been playing this for a few hours but felt compelled to write a review. Platform games work incredibly well in VR and you get totally immersed in this one.

The graphics are very good for this type of game.  It is a whimsical experience with a captivating story.  The narrative voice is done very well, they could surely make a living out of reading for audiobooks. Ha. I think there is a nice balance between the combat portion and the puzzles you must solve; it's not to tough, yet not so easy that it's boring. You may run into a couple of bugs, I did, but it's nothing that can't be overlooked. There were a couple of spots that I went through the map, but I restarted at the check point and continued on. I'd 100% recommend the game if you are looking for a sweet, magical, and relaxing gaming experience.

Visually the game looks fantastic.  The puzzles make you think a little, they stimulate your brain.  The story and characters are interesting.  Even though the levels are divided into several small sections, I love the way the game makes you feel like you are traveling, venturing into the unknown by displaying beautiful backgrounds.  I'm glad I bought this game on sale, because it's a little bit too short.  I usually don't complain about how short games are, but the release price of this game was too much !  Glad they lowered the price, but $30 is still a little bit too much.  Spoiler alert !  The game has a small ending with revealing plans of a continuation.  This is what pisses me off with the way things are going in the video game industry.  It feels like you are playing a fraction of the game.  So you might end up paying $100+ for this game in the long run if you buy it at regular price.  Don't get me wrong, it's a good game, that's why I gave it five stars, I  just don't agree with the price.

review_title: Deafie here -- thank you for subtitles
one_reviews_text:
Thank you for the subtitles!  I do want to consider more "pipboy-style" wrist mounted subtitles in some VR games, much like what "Red Matter" does -- it is more immersive.

That said, having subtitles at all is so much better than having no subtitles!   Many VR games, including big studios (Industrial Light & Magic / Lucasfilm / Disney) stilll omit subtitles from even big titles such as Star Wars.  But not you; you included subtitles and for that is an automatic 5-star from me.

Also, some people informed me that a group at Gallaudet University (a deaf university in Maryland) is considering a lawsuit to Oculus to force better disclosure of which VR games has subtitles or not -- like "Subtitles: Yes" versus "Subtitles: No".   Many accidental purchases of VR games and dissapointments have occured.  Steam has better disclosure but Oculus has a lot of great content.

review_title: potentially perfect too hard later on
one_reviews_text:
Positives: Your in a briar mouse miniature world of a mouse, graphically the game enchants you beautiful music & story likewise,
Negatives: the game in my opinion is spoilt by its difficulty curve later on, hermit crab & entrance to the castle, the difficulty of these fights ramp up, the hermit crab a strategy is needed which is not obvious, the hermit crab boss is almost as large as the central platform, meaning you are more prone to falling off in this fight and dying that way an ignoble death, the move set you set have which is the darting attack seems to make you more prone to falling of platforms somehow worse than the prior spin attack, charging up the sword mid fight? it feels there is no time. I think this game tries to ride a line between puzzles & combat which often overwhelms, & build agreived frustration in the player, the solution for the latter hermit crab phase imo opinion is to go range from an outer platform and & move position to an opposing side of the little platform on each of his 3 volley launches if timed right his fireball always lands where you were when he launched it, then conduct two charge range attacks shots and repeat, some say his rear is more vulnerable not sure? but close up comabt is death, if you go wrong, you can heal in the down time at the end of his three volleys. At the gate to the castle the number of mobs coming and from various directions just made me switch it off, if they left the emphasis on the puzzles and made the combat fights not so aggregious it would be more bearable, too many units to handle at many points, with one hand controlling one enemy unit whilst controlling quil with the other, for people of a certain  age theres just too much to handle, a simple solution is to accept one difficulty curve is not suitable for all and have some difficulty modes, also the game isnt adaptive, so if you fail on a fight forty times in a row, the game doesnt not alter difficulty to let you pass to see later content.

review_title: Very Nice Adventure with a Cute Mouse
one_reviews_text: Excellent VR game which I highly recommend.  Mildly challenging puzzles and action, although some later parts became quite difficult in terms of getting the mouse to avoid the hazards.  I did not realize that there were optional parts to the game until I was mostly finished, so I will be going through again to experience more of the game.  It was a relief to play Moss after recently having finished Obduction, which was sometimes a chore to make progress in.

Moss shares similarites to lucky's tale however improves on it in every way. Having the camera stationary does wonders for those prone to motion sickness. With lucky's tale I'd have a friend try it and they would step away sick within a few moments. Staying stationary in Moss provides a better experience.

This game is beautiful. The scenes are detailed and all those details build up the world Moss takes place in. Those with a Rift S will get the most out of this game with it's extra clarity. Having the better screen just makes it easier to become immersed in the story.

The story is good. Considering most VR games don't even have a story that's an amazing accomplishment. Be warned the dialogue isn't always suburb and can be cringy at times but overall it adds much more than it takes away. The voice acting is similar in that a more varried cast of voices would benifit the game however what it does have is much better than nothing. 

Gameplay is good. Puzzles are varried and some take real thought. There are lots of different puzzle/combat elements to keep the player from getting bored. 

Worth the buy!

An amazing, enchanting game.  Worth every penny.  This is a MUST own VR game.
What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said?  I guess I would just need to say that this is a game that simply MUST be in your game library!  Although some may say it is short, I say that it is a satisfying and thoughtfully moving game that was neither too short nore too long. 
Please support the people who made this game and purchase it so we can get more VR titles like this!  There is also free DLC being added and the first one is wonderful so that is even more reason to check this game out!

Really well made game with fantastic art direction. The 2D videos for this game do not do it justice. Once you're in VR it is incredible smooth and immersive with a great story. The in game cinematic elements were amazing and had me fully tuned in to what was happening. Can't wait for Book 2.

I was a little nervous about Moss, because I was afraid there might be parts of the game that I wouldn't be able to play. I'm severely handicapped, and as a result I can only playing games that can be played Sitting, and even some Sitting games are unplayable for me. I can move my upper body freely, but I can't bend down or swivel around. Because of the nature of the puzzles in Moss, I was concerned that some objects might be out of reach.

Fortunately, I only ran into 2 places where I needed to be able to reach down beyond my range, and luckily in both cases I was able to hold the headset above my head and temporarily reset my view for those particular puzzles. It was a little frustrating (thus the 4-star rating, instead of 5-stars), but I was able to play the whole game and that's what really mattered.

I'm about 30 minutes in and already ready for Moss 2 or another game like this.  So many people, including myself, think of VR and can only imagine a first person experience being of value.  That's understandable, it is virtual "reality", but once you remember it's meant for immersion not just another form of realism you find games like Moss.

Moss reminds me of Ori and the Blind Forest in the manner of story and beauty, but with Moss, I also get the immersive effect.  It's an oddly satisfying experience to be able to look around and see the environment around me even though it's a platformer game.  Or peek over the top of a branch and see some deer that I only would've seen if the developers had allowed it in that view.

That to me is what makes VR great, and I can't wait to see more.  What we consider "nuggest" or "easter eggs" in other games are just environment in VR games.  Give me games like this where I control a character as with any other game but the feeling of actually being there, overlooking, and the chance to peek around the corner and see something new.... or not see anything at all.

Is Moss the greatest game I've ever played... no, it is not.  But, I'm only 30 minutes in and can't wait to get 30 more.

[Why 4 stars you ask if I speak so highly of it.  That is purely because Moss, though nice so far, does have extremely minor things keeping it from 5 stars. And remember, it's possible some of these minor things may go away the further in I get.  If Moss had more girth to the game itself (the story so far is well done) such as abilities, xp, enchancements to get, it would've gained that 5th star.  So, if you are considering Moss, I say buy it.  I think you'll enjoy it.  If like me, the little things you wish it had that doesn't you know will come in time as games like this or developers like this expand.  I can't wait for Moss 2 or the next game like it.]

[Update: I can 100% say that after completing the game.  I'm still very happy with it]

I sincerely hope to see a Moss 2 (or more from this developer for that matter). I haven't made a VR review until now, as I feel this game deserves it. I own and play various VR games from DCS World (combat flight simulator) to games like H3VR, Robo Recall, etc.; and this game is the best sit-down VR dedicated game I've played.

You'll get about 3 hours of gameplay out of Moss (slightly more or less depending on your play style) and while that may seem a bit short, keep in mind this game was developed from the ground up for VR. There's nothing in this game that suggest corners were cut. This game is absolutely POLISHED for VR - a AAA VR game if you will.  You can tell a lot of hardwork went into Moss; everything from the Graphics (using the Unreal Engine), to the music, the sounds, the story,  the gameplay, and voice acting. It's all just nearly perfect.

If you want to see what future lies ahead for VR sit-down casual gaming, $30 will get you that experience. If you're eyeballing Moss...just buy it. Seriously.

review_title: Excellent VR platforming while it lasts.
one_reviews_text:
This game is short.  I finished it in under 4 hours.  However it is a good example of how to make effective and engaging platforming for VR by requiring you to physically interact with the environment while also controlling your character.  Being a seated experience is a nice break from more active VR games, and it sets the mood as a narrative-driven game that starts you out reading a story from a book.  Unlike other VR platformers that have the camera follow the character, Moss treats each room as it's own stage, uch like turning the pages in a pop-up book or viewing a set of dioramas.

When you finish the game you get an acheivement "a good beginning", which says a lot about how the game ends pretty quickly and leaves you wanting.  The ending felt like an introduction to a larger story and I expected it to keep going, but instead it ducked out and left me sitting alone in a cold library.  There is plenty of room where they can go with this style of platforming, and it feels like it doesn't live up to its potential.  It is obvious at the end that they plan on writing new chapters, but I wished they alluded to that from the beginning or in the title that this would be an episodic game.

There are also collectibles in the game that I have no idea what their purpose is.

I really can't say a bad thing about this game. Level design, pacing, art, gameplay, story, puzzles, voice acting are all top notch. And the price is a bargain. It might only be 3-4 hours long but what you get is really well thought out and designed and I don't think it needs to be longer. Well done team.

review_title: Cute but gameplay could use work
one_reviews_text:
A lot of reviews seem to be focusing on the story and the graphics, which admittedly are impressive. But after the “wow” factor fades, there are some issues with the gameplay, which is really the most important part of any game. There are some blind spots in some areas that can be annoying. The part I found most frustrating was how slow Quill is to respond to inputs. This is really noticeable in fights with swarms of enemies. I am trying to hit and dodge, and she is so slow to do either. You can help her in fights by holding down enemies while fighting with her, but this requires some very awkward hand placement with simultaneous finger inputs.
I don’t know how close I am to finishing, but this game seems really short for the price. I am willing to spend a little extra right now to encourage more studios to produce quality VR games. However, I think I would advise players to wait until this goes on sale before purchasing it.

I agree with what others have said about this rekindling the feeling of wonder from childhood, and the graphics, music, animation, story, attention to detail and everything were just superb! I'm eagerly awaiting a sequel!

What I found particularly interesting and clever was having the player control the protagonist, while not 'being' them exactly. Instead, you help Quill, take part in her journey along with her, and it develops a wonderful bond that wouldn't be there if you 'were' the protagonist, which is something that similar games like Chronos lacked. Being able to interact directly with the environment using my hands to help with puzzles was a great way of combining the appeal of console platformers with the unique capabilities of VR, building on what works rather than trying to reinvent the wheel. I also felt that using mice as characters was inspired, as it allowed for them and their world to be 'actual size' in a way that's not the case with scaled-down humans. Plus it was interesting seeing the worldbuilding, with them using squirrels instead of horses and such!

This is definitely one of the best VR games I've played so far - maybe THE best - and I'd recommend it to anyone and everyone! Very well done, developers!

review_title: One of the best VR games ever!!!
one_reviews_text:
This game is easily worth $100 - but luckily we get the best games on the entire planet for next to nothing! Moss may already be on my top 3 of best games ever made (at least within it's genre). It's not 5/5, it's probably 8/5 (compared to other 5/5 games except Lone Echo, of course). You control a mouse in 3rd person and you're in the gameworld in 1st person. Graphics are simply breathtakingly awesome, and although gameplay does remind you of Kin and possibly Chronos, Moss bows to no one. If you have a Rift headset, Moss is the game to get - when you're done with Lone Echo :-) Moss works perfectly forcing super-sampling 2.0 using an oc'ed GTX 1080.
Moss is played sitting down, but do stand up now and then to check you're not missing any secrets. Note, by default graphics are set to low when starting the game for the first time, remember to set graphics to high. The game isn't that taxing on current hardware, I wouldn't be surprised if GTX 1060 6GB owners can enable super-sampling 1.5 with high graphics setting and no frame dropping. This is probably the best VR game arriving in 2018 - and don't rush it, take your time to enjoy the world and find all the secrets, then this game may take 6 to 8 hours to complete.
